verses.text: The portion allotted to the tribe of Judah, by their clans, was from the territory bordering Edom, to the Wilderness of Zin southward, at the farthest southern edge.
verses.comment: Judah's inheritance begins at the southern border near Edom. This sets up Judah's significance as the chief tribe, related to Messianic prophecy in Genesis 49:10.

verses.text: Their southern border started from the end of the Dead Sea, at the bay facing southward,
verses.comment: The southern point begins at the Dead Sea, reinforcing the geographical reality and showing God's precise fulfillment of covenant land.

verses.text: And it passed south of the ascent of Akrabbim, went along to Zin, and went up south of Kadesh-barnea, then passed along Hezron, ascended to Addar, and turned toward Karka.
verses.comment: Includes landmarks relevant to tribal division. The ascent of Akrabbim also appears in Judges, marking wilderness trials before entry.

verses.text: From there it passed to Azmon and continued to the Brook of Egypt. Its border ended at the Mediterranean Sea. This is Judah’s southern boundary.
verses.comment: The ‘Brook of Egypt’ is key, later marking the edge for the land promised to Abraham (Genesis 15:18). Mediterranean frontier underlines the openness to the nations.

verses.text: The eastern border was the Dead Sea, up to the mouth of the Jordan. The northern border began from the bay of the sea, at the mouth of the Jordan.
verses.comment: The boundaries form God’s purposeful design. Eastern and northern limits emphasize the visible reach of Judah, foreshadowing Christ’s coming from Judah’s line.

verses.text: The border ascended to Beth-hoglah, and passed north of Beth-arabah; and the boundary went up to the stone of Bohan son of Reuben.
verses.comment: Naming these towns roots the story in historical geography, strengthening the sense of God’s covenant fidelity.

verses.text: The border went up to Debir from the Valley of Achor, and so northward, turning toward Gilgal, which is opposite the ascent of Adummim, south of the valley; and the border passed to the waters of En-shemesh and ended at En-rogel.
verses.comment: Gilgal is notable as a place of renewal for the Israelites—a baptismal motif, hinting at sacraments later in Christian tradition.

verses.text: Then the border went up by the Valley of Ben-Hinnom, to the southern slope of the Jebusite city (that is, Jerusalem); then the boundary went up to the top of the mountain overlooking the Valley of Hinnom westward, which is at the end of the Valley of Rephaim northward.
verses.comment: Jerusalem is first mentioned as Jebusite, later the site of the Temple and essential in salvation history. The mention prepares the way for Christ’s Passion in Jerusalem.

verses.text: From the top of the mountain, the border curves to the spring of the waters of Nephtoah, then to the cities of Mount Ephron, and bends to Baalah (that is, Kiriath-jearim).
verses.comment: Kiriath-jearim later becomes where the Ark of the Covenant rested—a motif of God’s presence among His people.

verses.text: The border turns from Baalah westward to Mount Seir, passes along to the northern slope of Mount Jearim (that is, Chesalon), and descends to Beth-shemesh, then passes by Timnah.
verses.comment: Beth-shemesh is a priestly city, highlighting God’s provision for liturgical service and worship.

verses.text: The border goes out to the slope north of Ekron, then curves to Shikkeron, passes by Mount Baalah, and continues to Jabneel. The boundary ends at the Mediterranean Sea.
verses.comment: Ekron and Jabneel are Philistine border towns, providing context for later spiritual battles between Israel and its neighbors.

verses.text: The western border is the Mediterranean Sea. This is the territory of the tribe of Judah by their clans.
verses.comment: The sea boundary communicates Judah’s place as a gateway to the world; all tribes would unite from here in God’s progressive revelation.

verses.text: Joshua gave to Caleb son of Jephunneh a portion among the people of Judah, according to the LORD’s command to Joshua, Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), Arba being forefather of Anak.
verses.comment: Caleb’s special inheritance highlights faithfulness rewarded. Hebron’s future as a patriarchal burial site points to historical continuity of God’s promises.

verses.text: And Caleb drove out from there the three sons of Anak: Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai, descendants of Anak.
verses.comment: Caleb’s conquest typifies overcoming giants—themes of spiritual warfare and perseverance in faith.

verses.text: From there he went up against the inhabitants of Debir, which was formerly called Kiriath-sepher.
verses.comment: Name change marks spiritual transformation—Debir’s name hints at ‘word’ or ‘oracle,’ a foreshadowing of divine revelation.

verses.text: Caleb said, “Whoever attacks and captures Kiriath-sepher, I will give my daughter Achsah as a wife.”
verses.comment: Marriage alliance through valor reflects family and community as sources of strength in divine plan, with sacramental undertones to Christian union.

verses.text: And Othniel, son of Kenaz, Caleb’s brother, captured it; so Caleb gave him his daughter Achsah as a wife.
verses.comment: Othniel foreshadows righteous leadership; he later becomes Israel’s first judge, a precursor to divinely-appointed spiritual authority.

verses.text: When she came, she urged Othniel to ask for a field from Caleb. Achsah got down from her donkey, and Caleb said to her, “What do you want?”
verses.comment: Achsah’s initiative affirms the value of seeking gifts from faithful fathers—spiritual inheritance is requested, spiritual blessings received.

verses.text: She said, “Give me a blessing. Since you have given me land in the Negev, give me also springs of water.” So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
verses.comment: The request for water symbolizes grace and spiritual sustenance, reminiscent of Christ’s living water in John 4:14.

verses.text: This is the inheritance of the tribe of Judah by their clans.
verses.comment: Judah’s inheritance is mentioned to emphasize the fulfillment of Jacob’s prophecy regarding leadership and future salvation.

verses.text: The cities in the extreme south of Judah’s territory, close to the border of Edom, were: Kabzeel, Eder, Jagur,
verses.comment: Listing these towns roots the text in historical fact, laying the groundwork for understanding Israel’s liturgical life.

verses.text: Kinah, Dimonah, Adadah,
verses.comment: These towns show the extensive scope of Israel’s settlement—covenant fulfillment is both communal and personal.

verses.text: Kedesh, Hazor, Ithnan,
verses.comment: Catalogues of towns express the real inheritance God prepared for His people.

verses.text: Ziph, Telem, Bealoth,
verses.comment: Ziph is the area where David later hid, evoking themes of spiritual refuge and trust in God.

verses.text: Hazor-hadattah, Kerioth-hezron (that is, Hazor),
verses.comment: Hezron is connected to genealogies of Christ in Matthew 1:3, establishing lineage and fulfillment.

verses.text: Amam, Shema, Moladah,
verses.comment: Moladah later becomes a Levitical city, showing God’s providence for priestly ministry.

verses.text: Hazar-gaddah, Heshmon, Beth-pelet,
verses.comment: The city lists later recur as sites for resettlement after exile, reinforcing hope in restoration.

verses.text: Hazar-shual, Beersheba, Biziothiah,
verses.comment: Beersheba is significant as a patriarchal altar; Abraham and Isaac worshiped God there, highlighting continuity and covenant mediation.

verses.text: Baalah, Iim, Ezem,
verses.comment: Baalah’s name suggests worship; Israel’s inheritance is shaped by proper, ordered worship.

verses.text: Eltolad, Kesil, Hormah,
verses.comment: Hormah is tied to Israel’s earlier defeat and later victory, a cycle reflected in spiritual perseverance.

verses.text: Ziklag, Madmannah, Sansannah,
verses.comment: Ziklag becomes a refuge for David, presaging Christ’s offering of spiritual refuge to the faithful.

verses.text: Lebaoth, Shilhim, Ain, Rimmon. In all: twenty-nine cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Lists of cities confirm historical reliability and show God’s gift of complete inheritance—reflecting fullness and unity of God’s people.

verses.text: In the lowland: Eshtaol, Zorah, Ashnah,
verses.comment: Eshtaol and Zorah are where Samson operates; spatial geography ties salvation history together with God calling His servants from this area.

verses.text: Zanoah, Engannim, Tappuah, Enam,
verses.comment: Engannim means ‘spring of gardens’—water imagery is persistent, symbolizing God’s grace and ongoing life.

verses.text: Jarmuth, Adullam, Socoh, Azekah,
verses.comment: Adullam is where David formed a community—signifying the beginning of rightly-ordered spiritual fellowship.

verses.text: Shaaraim, Adithaim, Gederah, Gederothaim: fourteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Shaaraim appears in the context of David’s victory over Goliath, a preview of divine assistance to God’s chosen.

verses.text: Zenan, Hadashah, Migdal-gad,
verses.comment: Migdal-gad means ‘tower of Gad’—symbolizing strength, a recurring spiritual image (cf. Prov. 18:10).

verses.text: Dilean, Mizpeh, Joktheel,
verses.comment: Mizpeh is a place for covenant-making and renewal of faith—a theme bearing on Christian liturgy and spiritual renewal.

verses.text: Lachish, Bozkath, Eglon,
verses.comment: Lachish is site of Canaanite resistance and later, prophetic judgment—foreshadowing themes of spiritual victory.

verses.text: Cabbon, Lahmam, Kitlish,
verses.comment: Villages serve the larger cities, hinting at the structure and order in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Gederoth, Beth-dagon, Naamah, Makkedah: sixteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Makkedah links to Joshua’s major battle, prefiguring Christ’s ultimate spiritual victory over sin and death.

verses.text: Libnah, Ether, Ashan,
verses.comment: Libnah is central in Israel’s conquests, reflecting firm leadership and unity—virtues of Christian community.

verses.text: Iphtah, Ashnah, Nezib,
verses.comment: Names endure in liturgical memory, marking the permanence of spiritual heritage.

verses.text: Keilah, Achzib, Mareshah: nine cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Keilah is where David protects the city—serving as a model for spiritual leadership rooted in care of God’s people.

verses.text: Ekron, with its towns and villages,
verses.comment: Ekron foreshadows conflict with pagan practices, urging the faithful toward spiritual purity.

verses.text: From Ekron to the west, all that were near Ashdod, with their villages;
verses.comment: Ashdod’s later inclusion links to the Ark’s journey, connecting God’s presence to the land.

verses.text: Ashdod, its towns and villages; Gaza, its towns and villages; as far as the Brook of Egypt and the Mediterranean Sea.
verses.comment: Gaza—future site of both blessing and trial—links the legacy of inheritance with spiritual struggle.

verses.text: In the hill country: Shamir, Jattir, Socoh,
verses.comment: Jattir becomes a Levitical holding, a visible sign of God’s provision for the spiritual needs of His people.

verses.text: Dannah, Kiriath-sannah (that is, Debir),
verses.comment: Debir’s alternate name points to the importance of place—not just physical, but for the transmission of God’s instruction.

verses.text: Anab, Eshtemoh, Anim,
verses.comment: More Levitical cities, expanding the network of God’s ordered worship.

verses.text: Goshen, Holon, Giloh: eleven cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Goshen is a place of refuge, tying Israel’s collective memory to God’s deliverance.

verses.text: Arab, Dumah, Eshean,
verses.comment: The succession of towns underscores the completeness of Judah’s gift, a motif recurring in Christian ideas of inheritance.

verses.text: Janum, Beth-tappuah, Aphekah,
verses.comment: Beth-tappuah means ‘house of apple’—symbols of restoration and fruitfulness, echoing spiritual abundance.

verses.text: Humtah, Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), Zior: nine cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Hebron is the burial place of the patriarchs—symbolizing continuity and resurrection hope.

verses.text: Maon, Carmel, Ziph, Juttah,
verses.comment: Carmel is a later site for Elijah’s contest, forecasting future spiritual victory.

verses.text: Jezreel, Jokdeam, Zanoah,
verses.comment: Jezreel forms the backdrop for prophetic ministry—showing how God’s land supports the mission of His people.

verses.text: Kain, Gibeah, Timnah: ten cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Gibeah is a well-known location later in salvation history—reminding us of the communal aspect of holiness.

verses.text: Halhul, Beth-zur, Gedor,
verses.comment: Beth-zur’s fortification points to themes of spiritual protection and defensive virtues.

verses.text: Maarath, Beth-anoth, Eltekon: six cities with their villages.
verses.comment: The completeness in numbers is significant—a pattern of perfection in biblical numerology.

verses.text: Kiriath-baal (that is, Kiriath-jearim), and Rabbah: two cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Kiriath-jearim is important for the Ark’s journey—a model for sacred objects in worship tradition.

verses.text: In the wilderness: Beth-arabah, Middin, Secacah,
verses.comment: Wilderness towns evoke trials and purification, supporting spiritual growth.

verses.text: Nibshan, the City of Salt, and En-gedi: six cities with their villages.
verses.comment: En-gedi is a place of refuge for David, connecting spiritual safety to places of retreat and prayer.

verses.text: But the people of Judah could not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem. So the Jebusites dwell with the people of Judah at Jerusalem to this day.
verses.comment: The incomplete conquest foreshadows future victory through an anointed king—pointing forward to David (2 Sam. 5:6) and ultimately to the Messiah. Spiritually, it can speak to the persistence required in the journey toward holiness, with Jerusalem later becoming the center for worship and sacrifice, shaping Christian understanding of liturgical worship and the communion of believers.
